thread.title: On "Feds Did a Sweep," Future Is at His Best, Rapping About Pain
thread.title_full: On "Feds Did a Sweep," Future Is at His Best, Rapping About Pain

author: Paul A. Thompson
title: On "Feds Did a Sweep," Future Is at His Best, Rapping About Pain
text:
Future “Feds Did a Sweep” 
It's difficult to hear “ Feds Did a Sweep," the closing song from Future ’ s new self-titled album, without thinking back to the “ March Madness ” video. That clip, for the anthemic 56 Nights single, was interspersed with footage of police officers murdering black civilians. “ Feds ” is itself interrupted by the police banging at the door, waving a warrant, picking “ the dawgs up like an infant. ” At the end of an album—and really, a larger creative period for Future—where time is hazy, even flat, and where stories are recalled in bits and pieces rather than a clean narrative arc, “ Feds ” is heavy with perspective, and with a sense of consequence. 
In recent years, Future has rendered his romantic and sexual relationships in ways that make them seem cold, even adversarial. Here, he raps about being “ idolized by these groupies ” who sneak iPhone pictures of him, then punctuating the scene, “ Preying on me, I ’ m the predator/Preying on me, I ’ m the predator. ” If that sort of mindset seems like it would be all-consuming, it is; in the first verse, he raps, “ You don ’ t wanna feel my pain/It ’ s gon ’ drive you insane. ” And yet, he ’ s at his most effective when he turns the lens outward: “ The sheriff wanna remain nameless/Tryin ’ to be Instagram famous. ” It's a cutting observation in a song whose title could be a New York Times headline.
